RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: Rudi Rocha possui graduação e mestrado em economia pela UFRJ e doutorado em economia pela PUC-Rio. É professor associado da Escola de Administração de Empresas de São Paulo da Fundação Getúlio Vargas (FGV EAESP). Vencedor de prêmios e grants internacionais, como o Haralambos Simeonidis (Anpec), o Newton Advanced Fellowship (Academia Britânica) e o Grand Challenges Explorations (Fundação Bill & Melinda Gates). É coordenador de pesquisa do Instituto de Estudos para Políticas de Saúde (IEPS), professor adjunto licenciado do IE-UFRJ, presidente do Conselho Científico do Instituto Escolhas e membro do Comitê Científico do Núcleo Ciência pela Infância (NPCI). Foi pesquisador associado ao ESRC Research Centre on Micro-Social Change (2015-2019), vice-presidente da Sociedade Brasileira de Econometria (2014-2015) e coordenador brasileiro da LACEA/IADB/World Bank/UNDP Research Network on Inequality and Poverty (2004-2008). Sua produção acadêmica tem aparecido em periódicos nacionais e internacionais de destaque, como o Economic Journal, American Economic Journal: Applied, Review of Economics and Statistics, Journal of Development Economics, The Lancet, Journal of Health Economics, dentre outros. Suas principais linhas de pesquisa incluem: demografia econômica e economia da saúde, economia do meio-ambiente, desenvolvimento econômico. Mais informações no site pessoal: www.rudirocha.org.
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: Rudi Rocha has an undergraduate and master's degree in Economics from UFRJ and a doctorate in Economics from PUC-Rio. He is an associate professor at Fundação Getulio Vargas' School of Business Administration in São Paulo (FGV EAESP). He is a winner of international awards and grants such as the Haralambos Simeonidis (Anpec), the Newton Advanced Fellowship (British Academy) and the Grand Challenges Explorations (Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation). He is the head of research at the Instituto de Estudos para Políticas de Saúde (IEPS), an adjunct professor at IE-UFRJ (on leave) , president of the Scientific Council of Instituto Escolhas and member of the Scientific Committee of Núcleo Ciência pela Infância (NPCI). He was a research associate at the ESRC Research Center on Micro-Social Change (2015-2019), vice president of the Brazilian Society of Econometrics (2014-2015) and Brazilian coordinator of the LACEA/IADB/World Bank/UNDP Research Network on Inequality and Poverty (2004-2008). His academic production has appeared in leading international journals such as the Economic Journal, American Economic Journal: Applied, The Review of Economics and Statistics, The Lancet, Journal of Health Economics, among others. His main research interests include Economic Demography and Health Economics, Environmental Economics, and Economic Development. More information on his personal website: www.rudirocha.org.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: The Effect of Rural Credit on Deforestation: Evidence from the Brazilian Amazon
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
In 2008 the Brazilian government made the concession of rural credit in the Amazon
conditional upon stricter requirements as an attempt to curb forest clearings. This paper
studies the impact of this innovative policy on deforestation. Difference-in-differences
estimation based on a panel of municipalities shows that the policy change led to a
substantial reduction in deforestation, mostly in municipalities where cattle ranching is
the leading economic activity. The results suggest that the mechanism underlying these
effects was a restriction in access to rural credit, one of the main support mechanisms for
agricultural production in Brazil
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: The Effect of Rural Credit on Deforestation: Evidence from the Brazilian Amazon

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Deforestation Slowdown in the Brazilian Amazon: Prices or Policies?
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
This paper investigates the contribution of agricultural output prices and policies to the
2000s reduction in Amazon deforestation. Based on a panel of Amazon municipalities
from 2002 through 2009, we first show that deforestation responded to agricultural output
prices. After controlling for price effects, we find that conservation policies implemented
beginning in 2004 and 2008 significantly contributed to the curbing of deforestation.
Counterfactual simulations suggest that conservation policies avoided approximately 73,000
square kilometers of deforestation, or 56% of total forest clearings that would have occurred
from 2005 through 2009 had the policies adopted beginning in 2004 and 2008 not been
introduced. This is equivalent to an avoided loss of 2.7 billion tonnes of stored carbon
dioxide
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Deforestation Slowdown in the Brazilian Amazon: Prices or Policies?

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Copayment of Prescription Drugs, Health Care Utilization and Health Outcomes: Evidence from a Developing Country
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
This paper evaluates the impact of a drug co-payment policy, Aqui Tem Farmácia Popular (ATFP),
on mortality and hospitalization rates in Brazil
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Copayment of Prescription Drugs, Health Care Utilization and Health Outcomes: Evidence from a Developing Country

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Does Universalization of Health Work? Evidence from Health Systems Restructuring
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
We investigate a major restructuring of the health system in Brazil which was motivated
to operationalize the universalization of access to public health services. There
was a massive expansion of primary health facilities with GPs and outreach workers at
the community level, alongside a decline in the density of hospital facilities and specialists
per capita. We assimilate administrative data from several sources to obtain
information on programme implementation, local level health facilities, indicators of
access including hospitalization, and births and deaths by cause and age
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES:
We investigate a major restructuring of the health system in Brazil which was motivated
to operationalize the universalization of access to public health services. There
was a massive expansion of primary health facilities with GPs and outreach workers at
the community level, alongside a decline in the density of hospital facilities and specialists
per capita. We assimilate administrative data from several sources to obtain
information on programme implementation, local level health facilities, indicators of
access including hospitalization, and births and deaths by cause and age.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Does Universalization of Health Work? Evidence from Health Systems Restructuring

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
This paper examines the role of human capital persistence in explaining long-term
development. We exploit variation induced by a state-sponsored settlement policy
that attracted immigrants with higher levels of schooling to particular regions of Brazil
in the late 19th and early 20th century. We show that one century after the policy,
municipalities that received settlements had higher levels of schooling and income per
capita. We provide evidence that long-run effects were driven by the higher supply
of educational inputs and shifts in the structure of occupations towards skill-intensive
sectors

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Drug Battles and School Achievement: Evidence from Rio de Janeiro's Favelas
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
This paper examines the effects of gunghts between drug gangs in Rio de
Janeiro's favelas on student achievement. We explore variation in violence that
occurs across time and space when gangs battle over territories. Within-school
estimates indicate that students' scores are lower in math in years in which
they are exposed to drug battles. Our ndings suggest that the effect of violence
increases with conflict intensity, duration, and proximity to exam dates; and decreases with the distance between the school and the conflict location. Finally, we find that school supply is an important mechanism driving the achievement results; gunfights are associated with higher teacher absenteeism, principal turnover, and temporary school closings
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Drug Battles and School Achievement: Evidence from Rio de Janeiro's Favelas

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Water Scarcity and Birth Outcomes in the Brazilian Semiarid
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Roughly one-third of the rural population in developing countries lives in arid and semiarid regions, facing recurrent water scarcity. This is likely to become an even more common situationwith climate change. This paper analyzes the impact of rainfall fluctuations during the gestational period on health at birth in the Brazilian semiarid, highlighting the role of water scarcity as a determinant of early life health
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Water Scarcity and Birth Outcomes in the Brazilian Semiarid

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Impacts of Glyphosate Use in Agriculture on Human Health
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: The goal of this project is to assess the impact of glyphosate use on the health of human populations. This is a major issue in the current debate on the use of glyphosate and, more generally, of genetically modified seeds. We believe that this project can make an important contribution to this pressing public discussion. In Brazil, the use of glyphosate is concentrated on the production of soybeans and increased with the expansion of soybean planted area following the adoption of genetically modified seeds in the 2000s. This is the setting we will use for the analysis.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: The goal of this project is to assess the impact of glyphosate use on the health of human populations. PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Impacts of Glyphosate Use in Agriculture on Human Health

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Welfare Dependence and Poverty Traps: Evaluating the Contribution of Health Shocks and Health Policy Using Administrative Data
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
The objective is to investigate the extent to which public health provision
enhances the capacity for social protection. The poor are more vulnerable to
disease, and poor health can perpetuate poverty and welfare dependency. We will
contribute new evidence on synergies between income support and public health,
relevant to sustaining cash transfers on a wide scale, especially under austerity.
We also contribute to work on sustainable cities insofar as we study epidemics
that diffuse more rapidly in dense urban areas.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES:
The objective is to investigate the extent to which public health provision

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Welfare Dependence and Poverty Traps: Evaluating the Contribution of Health Shocks and Health Policy Using Administrative Data

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Access to Health Care, Health Outcomes and Hospital Performance in Brazilian Cities
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
The goal of this project is to assess how and to what extent the introduction of
Urgent Care Units (UPA 24hs) has affected health outcomes and the efficiency of the local public health system in Brazil (productivity indicators at the hospital level).
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES:

PARTICIPACAO-EM-PROJETO.NOME-ORGAO: Escola de Administração de Empresas de São Paulo

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Using Geocoded Big Data to Identify Causal Links Between Infectious Diseases and Child Developmental Outcomes
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Infectious diseases may have only transitory impacts on pregnant mothers, but they can have lasting impacts on children. Can public interventions mitigate these impacts? Our proposal is to identify how exposure to localized epidemiological risk factors in the foetal period influences developmental outcomes for children through the early years of life. We further propose to examine the extent to which access to primary health care and social welfare programs mitigates detrimental impacts.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Infectious diseases may have only transitory impacts on pregnant mothers, but they can have lasting impacts on children. Can public interventions mitigate these impacts? Our proposal is to identify how exposure to localized epidemiological risk factors in the foetal period influences developmental outcomes for children through the early years of life. We further propose to examine the extent to which access to primary health care and social welfare programs mitigates detrimental impacts.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Using Geocoded Big Data to Identify Causal Links Between Infectious Diseases and Child Developmental Outcomes

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Impacto de Políticas de Atenção Básica em Saúde e Educação: Evidências do Programa Saúde na Escola
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: O projeto de pesquisa em questão propõe-se a avaliar o impacto do Programa Saúde na Escola, uma política pública intersetorial criada em 2007, que financiou a articulação das redes de profissionais de saúde da família ao dia-a-dia das escolas públicas brasileiras, provendo diretrizes para a provisão de atenção básica aos escolares.

PARTICIPACAO-EM-PROJETO.NOME-ORGAO: Escola de Administração de Empresas de São Paulo

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Stop Suffering! Economic Downturns and Pentecostal Upsurge
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
This paper estimates the effects of economic downturns on religious conversion to
Pentecostal Evangelicalism across Brazilian regions between 1991 and 2010. We find
that regions more exposed to economic distress experienced an increase in Pentecostal
affiliation during the 1990s, accompanied by a decrease in adherents to other Christian
denominations. Our estimates show that this conversion persisted over the following
decade. We also show that economic downturns are associated with the growth in the
vote share of candidates explicitly connected to Pentecostal churches in national elections
in both the short and long run. These results uncover a causal link between economic
distress and the political entrenchment of more fundamentalist religious groups
in a secular democracy.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES:
This paper estimates the effects of economic downturns on religious conversion to
Pentecostal Evangelicalism across Brazilian regions between 1991 and 2010. We find
that regions more exposed to economic distress experienced an increase in Pentecostal
affiliation during the 1990s, accompanied by a decrease in adherents to other Christian
denominations. Our estimates show that this conversion persisted over the following
decade. We also show that economic downturns are associated with the growth in the
vote share of candidates explicitly connected to Pentecostal churches in national elections
in both the short and long run. These results uncover a causal link between economic
distress and the political entrenchment of more fundamentalist religious groups
in a secular democracy.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Stop Suffering! Economic Downturns and Pentecostal Upsurge

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Do Lower Taxes Reduce Informality? Evidence from Brazil
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
We explore a unique, large-scale formalization program in Brazil to estimate the
effects of reducing the costs of formality on firm formalization. We rely on both
firm-level administrative data and individual panel data to show that reducing taxes
once registration costs have already been eliminated reduces firm informality. This
effect comes from the formalization of existing informal firms, and not from the
creation of new formal businesses nor greater formal firm survival. The implied
formalization elasticity is otherwise low, and our cost-benefit analysis indicates that
the program led to net losses in tax revenues.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES:
We explore a unique, large-scale formalization program in Brazil to estimate the
effects of reducing the costs of formality on firm formalization. We rely on both

once registration costs have already been eliminated reduces firm informality. This
effect comes from the formalization of existing informal firms, and not from the

formalization elasticity is otherwise low, and our cost-benefit analysis indicates that
the program led to net losses in tax revenues.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Do Lower Taxes Reduce Informality? Evidence from Brazil
